[COLOR="Blue"]Unlike so many people on here that are saying they KNOW that this myth called God, Christ and the hokus pokus things called "souls" do NOT exist and never have, I feel a bit different on those viewpoints. Here is a old post of mine on here from 2004 ..
 
 
 I was raised to go to church very Sunday until I was at least 13 years old, and then my parents said I could make my own choice as to whether to continue going to church or not. So, at 13, I chose to stop going to church at all anymore. My mother was a great woman, low in education, but savy in life , a life she lived hard and one not made any easier by raising 9 of us kids, on a poverty income during the Great Depression. She was a house Christian, to me meaning she did not ever go to church with us, but was raised a Christian, read her big old family Bible with vigor, and believed with all her heart that Christ was her Saviour.... 
 
 When I was 21 and living single in my own apartment, I made sure to visit Mom at least weekly to check on her , she at that time being a widow living alone. She was my favorite parent of the two, and we were always close, we could talk about anything with the upmost sincerity and honesty. Almost every visit, she would end it by asking me if I had any intention of going back to church. I always had the same reply to her, saying church had nothing to offer me, and that I didnt need it to teach me how to lead a good moral life , and that she had raised me just fine. But, she always countered by saying , " Church is not just to teach you about a moral life, its most important thing, is to teach you that Christ is your Saviour , and by accepting Him and believing in Him with all of your heart that He is your Saviour ,and by that belief, you will be saved fron damnation in Hell. " ....
 
 Now, that one always got my goat, so to speak. Those very same words were taught to me in Sunday school as a kid and I had not gotten a grasp of of them back then, and it made no more sense to me at 21 years of age. I was always respectful to Mom, so I would not go up against her with counter claim, but would just mumble something about I needed to get to the laundrymat before it closed, etc. So, I would give her a big hug and kiss and exit promply. But , as the years went by she continued reminding me that to be saved , I must turn my life over to Christ, be baptized in his name , to avoid the eternal fire and damnation....
 
 Finally, one pretty Sunday fall afternoon in 1982, I was visiting with her and having a good evening of chit chat. By now she was 78 years old and had a lot of physical ailments afflicting her. So, this day I was feeling more accomodating , and was willing to debate this fire and brimstone thing with her. As of yet, I still had not been back to church , and was not baptized . So, after she gave me her speech again about wanting me to go back to church and get baptized, her voiced sort of trailed off and a sadness came over her face. In her next sentence she said, " Son, I dont know how much longer I have here on earth, and I just dont want to lie down and die, and know that when I draw my last breath , that you are still not saved yet . " ...
 
 Well, her words kind of got to me and sort of stuck in my gizzard so to speak, so I opened up to her with what my feelings were, about this hell thing. I told her that in order for a person to be afraid of hell, they need to know, and be proven to them, that there is such a place, OR at LEAST prove to me, there is a afterlife. I told her that without a soul or spirit energy living on after physical death, THAT would make the concept of eternal torment hellfire , a complete impossibility in my mind. I asked her that in her long lifetime, had she ever had ANY aknowledgement of a person that had died, and then came back and proved to her that a afterlife existed ?. She replied with a no, and that it was just something she was raised to believe in, and she believed in her heart that Christ was real, and so was the afterlife...
 
 Being 29 now, and so worldly in my ways, I couldnt accept that. To me it just didnt make sense, and it had no logic to it at all. What ? Believe in something you cannot see, smell, or touch ?? Humbug , I thought. So , in my huge and wise 29 year old mind, I came up with a thought to make her PROVE to me a afterlife existed. I knew my Mom had NEVER (that I knew of anyway) mislead me about anything, or lied to me in my whole 29 years of living. So I had a thought...
 
 We sat there and wound down on the topic, her not winning, nor I for that matter. So, finally I rendered to her my ingenious, agnostic thought. I told Mom that by ALL probability, she would expire before I would, and she concured. So, my Mom and I made a pact that Sunday afternoon, and hugged on it, one that I knew in my heart I could trust her or myself, to live up to. She agreed to me, that if she died first, she would do something, ANY thing, to let me know her spirit/soul had lived on beyond her death. Even if it meant she had to carry a lamp across the room in front of me. So, every time I visted Mom thereafter for the following 10 years, the Christ and hell fire thing was never brought up again between us ...
 
 On August 13, 1992 in the late evening, the phone rang and my wife answered it. It was my sister calling from the nursing home, Mom had just passed away a hour ago, she said. She was found in her favorite chair, her Harlequin romance book still clutched in her hand, like she had just nodded off in to death. All arrangements were made, Mom was laid to rest beside Dad at the cemetery...
 
 About 45 days after Mom was buried, one night something really weird happened at my home. I recall it as if it was yesterday, the exact events of it. It was 2 am, when I was wakened by what I thought was a earthquake or at least a tremor, because my mattress was shaking rapidly from side to side. I thought I might just be in a "sleep/dream state" so I quickly sat up in the bed to tell my wife lying next to me about it. But she was not there. She and our chow dog both, were standing in the bedroom doorway . They both had their eyes bugged out, looking at me and the bed mattress moving side to side. I quickly asked my wife " Was it a tremor ? Was anything else on the walls shaking ? She said no, and by the time she said no, the mattress stopped moving from side to side. We both went back to bed and said no more about it...
 
 We both went to work the next day and at that time we worked different shifts . Finally, late that night we sat down to eat and I started the topic about the bed shaking side to side the night before. I asked her if I was crazy, making it up, or just had a nightmare. I let her tell me what she had experienced, without me telling my experience first. That way, I knew I would not be leading her in to saying something I had felt, I wanted to know what she had felt first. She told me that she was awakened by a violent side to side movement of the mattress about 2 am. When she opened her eyes, our chow dog , who always slept at the foot of the bed on the floor, was already in the bedroom door looking back at the bed, with its hair bristled and ears laid flat. She said as she ran to the bedroom door and looked back at me, I sat up and asked her was it a earthquake, and she said that the mattress was still moving side to side. SO, she had seen and felt what I had , without us ever discussing it, so it wasnt contrived by us or a nightmare shared by us....
 
 I never gave the incident anymore thought until one day about 3 months later a guy I worked with, a baby Christian it just so happened, was spouting scripture about the hellfire and brimstone. It instantly took my mind back to Mom, and our long chats about that subject . It even took me further back, to when as a child and even as a young teen, Mom awoke me every morning by putting her knee against the head of my mattress, and would violently shake it side to side, until I woke up.
